authority.ref: Representation and Reality: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives on the Aristotelian Tradition

The transcription has been normalized to classical orthography.

change.p: Created file for the first time.

div.p:
Of good and honourable things et cetera
Arist. DA I.1 402a1.
. In the second book of Physics, as he intends to investigate and present the boundaries and limits of the study of physics or the natural philosopher, the Philosopher says
to which extent the natural philosopher ought to investigate the species and essence
Arist. Ph. II.2 194b10--11.
, viz. what the limits are of the study of physics or the natural philosopher, which is concerned with species, viz. forms, which are the essences, viz. which are relevant to the definition of the essence. He answers
in the same passage
that in whichever way the doctor investigates nerves and the metallurgist bronze, so does the natural philosopher investigate the form or species and essence,
Arist. Ph. II.2 194b11--12.
as not any consideration of nerves pertains to the doctor, nor does whatever thing which can be known about bronze pertain to the metallurgist, and similarly is not every consideration of forms pertinent to the natural philosopher. We must therefore consider how these artificers investigate the mentioned subjects.

Let us consider what the different subject matters of the doctor, the metallurgist and the natural philosopher are. A doctor primarily seeks to produce good health, so when he investigates nerves, it aims at the production of good health, therefore whichever consideration of nerves, insofar as it strives for good health, pertains to the doctor, but if there is some other consideration that goes beyond this, it supersedes the doctor's investigation. Similarly, as the metallurgist focuses on the matter of artificial instruments, whichever investigation of bronze, insofar as it is the matter of artificial instruments, pertains to the metallurgist, but if there is some consideration that goes beyond this, it evades his consideration. From this it is apparent what the object of the natural philosopher's knowledge is and to which limit it extends. For whatever is considered by a natural philosopher is characterized by movement and change,
for the things which move but are not moved do not fall within the natural philosopher's subject matter
according to the Philosopher in the second book of Physics
Arist. Ph. II.7 198a26--30.
. Hence entirely immaterial forms which are not bound to the motion of matter and change of subjects, evade the subject matter of the physicist or natural philosopher. But forms which in one way are immaterial and in another way are the actuality of matter do fall within the subject matter of the natural philosopher or physicist, and that is the limit to which the physical consideration extends. But the human soul is that sort of form, and hence it is the limit and end of physical investigation.

And from this we can establish that there are three types of forms. For some are entirely immaterial, both with respect to their disposition and substance, and the intelligences, which exist without any sensible or intelligible matter
according to the Philosopher in book eight of Metaphysics,
Arist. Metaph. VIII.5 1044b27--29(?)
are of this sort; and some are entirely material, both with respect to their substance and disposition, since their substances and dispositions are realized from matter, and the forms of the lower beings are of this sort; but some are forms of a medial character which are immaterial with respect to their substance and material with respect to their disposition, and the human souls are of this sort. Hence the first forms are beyond the subject matter of the natural philosopher, but the physical investigation begins with the second forms and terminate with the third, for the subject matter of the natural philosopher begins with the inferior forms and stops with the human soul.

From this it is further apparent which rank this book holds among the books on natural philosophy, as the physical and the metaphysical mode of investigation in some way are opposed each other. For the natural philosopher's mode of investigation has a stopping point in the elevated but not in the low, for it has a stopping point with reference to the level of abstraction, which is an elevated area, since some are so abstract that they exceed the physical subject matter, and some are so abstract that the physical subject matter does not extend beyond them. But with reference to the level of materiality, which is a low level, the natural philosopher does not have a stopping point, for there is not another form so concrete with reference to matter that it evades the natural philosopher's subject matter. Thus the more concrete a form is with reference to matter, the more it falls within his subject matter, and this must be understood with view to the abstraction from singular items, for if we look to things individual and of numerical singularity, that exceeds the natural philosopher's subject matter. But the contrary holds for metaphysician's mode of investigation, since it has a stopping point in the low but not in the elevated, because some form is so concrete with respect to matter that the consideration of it does not pertain to the metaphysician, but there is no form so abstract that it exceeds the metaphysician's consideration, for metaphysics is concerned with the highest causes. Hence the more an investigation is concerned with abstract things, the more metaphysical it is. This must be understood with reference to subject matters based on human inquisition, for if there is some abstract subject matter which is acquired through inspiration, it exceeds the metaphysician's subject matter, but our present reflections are not of that sort.

Hence let us understand what has been said in the following way, that when there are three essential parts of philosophy (namely natural philosophy, mathematics, and divine science) among the arts or sciences invented through human inquisition, the metaphysician does not recognize any other higher science, but in terms of the level of abstraction natural philosophy does not recognize any other lower practitioner within the essential parts of philosophy, although there is a higher one, but the mathematician recognizes both a higher practice, since there is a more abstract one, and a lower, since there is one more concrete. Hence, as it has been said, the natural philosopher's subject matter takes its beginning with the lower forms and ends with the human soul, and from this it is apparent that On the soul holds the sixth place within the books on natural philosophy, for Physics holds the first place, On the heavens and earth the second, On generation and corruption the third, Meteorology the fourth, On minerals the fifth, and On the soul the sixth. It is therefore the first in order of dignity, although it is the final or sixth in the doctrinal order, and hence the
Philosopher says, with a view to its dignity,
that the description of the soul should be ranked among the first sciences.
Arist. DA I.1 402a1--7.
